admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
trustfund: TF040433-VIETNAM:  RURAL FINANCE II,TF040435-VIETNAM:  RURAL FINANCE II,TF040479-VIETNAM:  RURAL FINANCE II

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Rural Finance
            Project for Vietnam were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: when a government is taking a series of measures
            to improve conditions in rural areas, and rural term credit
            is in short supply, easing this constraint can have a major
            positive impact on rural incomes. It also leads to increases
            in access to other financial services such as use of savings
            deposits. Credit projects are likely to succeed when they
            are relatively straightforward in structure, provided that
            the broad financial sector reform issues have been or are
            being addressed at the same time. A local commercial bank,
            if suitably strengthened, may be in the best position to
            serve as an apex lending institution, provided that there is
            strong commitment from its senior management including
            willingness to provide the necessary resources to a Project
            Management Unit (PMU) and to set up an effective Monitoring
            and Evaluation (M&E) system. A strong PMU can be used as
            a training ground for its larger institution, provided the
            institution's senior management is committed to this
            rather than isolating the PMU. Private Banks can be
            attracted to significantly expand term credit in rural
            areas, provided they have access to longer-term funds and
            receive appropriate training and Technical Assistance (TA).
            It is feasible to have vigorous competition among banks,
            even in poor rural areas. Environmental standards can be
            introduced even for small sub-borrowers, provided that
            emphasis is given to education and not just regulation. This
            is especially important in activities like livestock and
            aquaculture. Job creation, in relation to investment
            amounts, is much greater for small subprojects than for
            larger ones. Beneficiary surveys should be built into credit
            projects, and should preferably be carried out by or at
            least with the participation of independent entities.
